title-group.article-title: Telling in Time (I): Chronology and Narrative Theory

p.mixed-citation:
Genette, where he is satisfied to affirm that "the order long consid- ered natural is nothing but one order among others" (1969: 221)
Genette
221 The order long considered natural is nothing but one order among others 1969

Rimmon-Kenan, a disciple of Genette's, who repeats the master's words but misrepresents his claim by grounding it in the pressures of multilinearity rather than in the preference for anachrony (1983: 16-17, 45-46) 16
Clark and Clark (1977: 506-8)506 Clark and Clark 1977

Todorov (whose terms reappear in Chatman's Story and Discourse [1978]
Todorov
Story and Discourse 1978
Notable among them is Propp, who lays it down as a law of the morphology of the folktale that "the sequence of functions is always identical" (1968 [1928])

Bakhtin / Medvedev, who would scrap the distinction altogether: "The material is artistic through and through. . ... Although we can separate story from plot as the Formalists under- stand it, the story itself is, nevertheless, artistically organized" [1985 (1928): 113]
Bakhtin
113 The material is artistic through and through. . ... Although we can separate story from plot as the Formalists understand it, the story itself is, nevertheless, artistically organized 1985
Aristotle, in opposing the logical to the chronological and insisting on "an achronological notion of narrative temporality" (1984: 38ff., 239, n. 20)

Voltaire, there is no history in the modern sense of the word, nothing but chronologies" (Barthes 1972: 86)
Voltaire
86 nothing but chronologies 1972

Bakhtin / Medvedev: "Life, the aggregate of defined actions, events, or experiences, only becomes plot [siuzhet], story 1[abula], theme, or motif once it has been refracted through the prism of the ideological environment, only once it has taken on con- crete ideological flesh. Reality that is unrefracted and, as it were, raw is not able to enter into the content of literature" (1985 [1928]: 17)
Bakhtin
17 Life, the aggregate of defined actions, events, or experiences, only becomes plot [siuzhet], story 1[abula], theme, or motif once it has been refracted through the prism of the ideological environment, only once it has taken on concrete ideological flesh. Reality that is unrefracted and, as it were, raw is not able to enter into the content of literature 1985
Small wonder that Kermode proceeds to oppose chronos to kairos, not to anything like "anachronos
